clinical_notes.aggressive:
CLINICAL NOTES - NEUROSURGERY DEPARTMENT
Patient ID: F46-B-DS
Primary Diagnosis: Meningioma
WHO Grade: II (Atypical Meningioma)

INITIAL VISIT - March 15, 2018
Chief Complaint: Progressive neurological symptoms with significant impact on daily functioning
Imaging: Initial MRI reveals a 4.2cm right frontal convexity meningioma with significant peritumoral edema and mass effect on adjacent structures. Evidence of dural tail sign. Non-calcified lesion with heterogeneous enhancement.

Assessment & Plan:
- Given size >3cm, peritumoral edema, and progressive symptoms, immediate surgical intervention recommended
- Pre-surgical optimization of diabetes management required
- Dexamethasone 4mg QID initiated for edema management
- Surgical planning for gross total resection within 2 weeks

SURGICAL NOTE - March 29, 2018
Procedure: Right frontal craniotomy for tumor resection
Simpson Grade: II
Findings: Firm, well-circumscribed tumor with significant vascularity
Pathology: WHO Grade II meningioma with increased mitotic activity

FOLLOW-UP VISIT - April 15, 2018
Post-operative MRI shows near-total resection
Symptoms improving
Initiated adjuvant radiation therapy plan: 54 Gy in 30 fractions

6-MONTH FOLLOW-UP - September 2018
MRI stable
Returned to work part-time
Headaches resolved
Vision normalized

ANNUAL FOLLOW-UP - March 2019
Surveillance MRI: No evidence of recurrence
Full-time work resumed
Maintaining good diabetes control

18-MONTH FOLLOW-UP - September 2019
MRI stable
All symptoms resolved
Regular diabetes monitoring continues

2-YEAR FOLLOW-UP - March 2020
Surveillance MRI: Small enhancement at resection site
Decision: Close monitoring with 3-month interval imaging

3-YEAR FOLLOW-UP - March 2021
MRI shows slight progression of enhancement
Decision: Gamma Knife radiosurgery to residual tumor
Treatment completed May 2021

4-YEAR FOLLOW-UP - March 2022
Post-radiosurgery MRI shows good response
No new symptoms
Continues full work schedule

5-YEAR FOLLOW-UP - March 2023
Stable imaging
No cognitive deficits
Excellent functional status

CURRENT VISIT - March 2024
6-year follow-up
MRI remains stable
Maintaining normal work and activities
Diabetes well-controlled

FUNCTIONAL STATUS SCORES:
Karnofsky Performance Status (KPS): 90%
- Able to carry on normal activity; minor signs/symptoms of disease

ECOG Performance Status: 1
- Restricted in physically strenuous activity but ambulatory and able to carry out light work

ONGOING MONITORING PLAN:
- Biannual MRI surveillance
- Regular neurocognitive assessments
- Continued diabetes management
- Annual ophthalmological evaluation
- Return to clinic sooner if new symptoms develop

Note: Given patient's cognitive-demanding occupation as a Data Scientist, aggressive early intervention was prioritized to preserve cognitive function and maintain career capabilities. Regular monitoring continues with emphasis on both tumor control and preservation of cognitive function.

ASSESSMENT:
WHO Grade I meningioma (presumptive radiological diagnosis)
Symptoms likely attributable to tumor location

ECOG: 1

Given patient's profession requiring fine balance and cognitive function, recommending close monitoring rather than immediate surgical intervention. Tumor size just below critical 3cm threshold.

RECOMMENDATIONS:
1. MRI surveillance every 4 months for first year

3. Dexamethasone 4mg daily for symptom management
4. Referral to neuro-ophthalmology for baseline assessment
5. Continue current migraine management

- Significant perilesional edema
- Mass effect on adjacent frontal lobe
- Enhancement pattern suggests possible WHO Grade II
- Evidence of dural tail sign

ASSESSMENT:
Patient presents with concerning neurological symptoms affecting quality of life and work performance. Given tumor size, location, and symptom progression, immediate surgical intervention recommended.

TREATMENT PLAN:
1. Schedule gross total resection within 2 weeks
2. Pre-operative optimization of blood pressure
3. Discussed risks/benefits with patient
4. Occupational considerations: visual/cognitive demands of librarian role warrant aggressive approach

-------------------

- Simpson Grade II resection achieved
- Pathology confirms WHO Grade II meningioma
- Minimal post-operative complications
- Adjuvant radiation therapy recommended

-------------------

FOLLOW-UP - October 15, 2014
- Post-radiation assessment
- Improved neurological symptoms
- MRI shows no residual tumor
- Return to work planned with modifications

-------------------

SURVEILLANCE VISIT - April 20, 2015
- 6-month MRI: No recurrence
- Headaches resolved
- Vision normalized
- Continuing q6month monitoring

-------------------

ANNUAL REVIEW - April 15, 2016
- MRI stable
- Working full-time
- Minor fatigue managed with lifestyle modifications
- BP well-controlled

-------------------

2-YEAR FOLLOW-UP - May 10, 2017
- Surveillance MRI: Small enhancement at resection margin
- Close monitoring recommended
- Increased scan frequency to q4months

-------------------

URGENT ASSESSMENT - February 12, 2018
- New enhancement on MRI
- Early recurrence suspected
- Second surgery planned

-------------------

POST-SECOND SURGERY - March 20, 2018
- Simpson Grade I resection achieved
- Pathology confirms recurrent WHO Grade II
- Additional course of radiation recommended

-------------------

5-YEAR SURVEILLANCE - April 15, 2019
- Stable imaging
- Excellent functional status
- Maintaining work schedule
- Annual MRI protocol initiated

-------------------

LATEST FOLLOW-UP - January 10, 2024
- 10-year surveillance
- No evidence of recurrence
- Fully functional at work
- Continues annual monitoring

- Karnofsky Performance Status (KPS): 90/100
- ECOG Performance Status: 1

MONITORING PROTOCOL:

- Quarterly neurological examinations
- Regular cognitive assessments
- Quality of life questionnaires

- Significant peritumoral edema

- Enhancement pattern consistent with meningioma

- No new symptoms

2021-2023 (q6mo visits):

CLINICAL NOTES - NEUROSURGERY DEPARTMENT

INITIAL VISIT - March 15, 2014
Patient: 59-year-old male
Chief Complaint: Progressive neurological symptoms

IMAGING:
MRI reveals a 4.2 cm left frontal convexity meningioma with significant peritumoral edema. Mass effect on adjacent frontal lobe with 5mm midline shift. T2 hyperintense with heterogeneous enhancement. No calcification noted.

ASSESSMENT:
WHO Grade II atypical meningioma (suspected based on imaging characteristics)
High-risk features:
- Size >3cm
- Significant peritumoral edema
- Prior radiation exposure history
- Symptomatic presentation
- Location near motor strip

PLAN:
1. Recommend immediate surgical resection
2. Pre-operative optimization of blood pressure
3. Dexamethasone 4mg QID for edema
4. Pre-operative functional MRI and DTI tractography
5. Discussed surgical risks and benefits with patient

SURGERY - April 2, 2014
Procedure: Left frontal craniotomy for tumor resection
Simpson Grade II resection achieved
Pathology confirms WHO Grade II atypical meningioma
Ki-67 proliferation index: 12%

FOLLOW-UP VISIT - July 15, 2014

Initiated adjuvant radiation therapy: 60 Gy in 30 fractions
Symptoms improving
Started physical therapy for right-sided weakness

FOLLOW-UP - January 10, 2015

No evidence of recurrence
Improved strength and gait
Continue q3 month monitoring

- Serial MRIs stable
- Maintained neurological improvement
- Regular cognitive assessments
- Managing obesity and sleep apnea

2.1 cm nodule
Recommend stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS)

2020-2022:

Stable disease
Annual neuropsychological testing
Managing cardiovascular risk factors

LATEST VISIT - January 2024
Stable disease on imaging
Maintained good functional status
Continue surveillance q6 months

ECOG Score: 1

Guarded due to Grade II status and radiation history
Maintaining aggressive surveillance due to risk factors

3. Initial tumor size and location
4. Patient's age and comorbidities

clinical_notes.aggressive:
CLINICAL NOTES - NEUROSURGERY DEPARTMENT
Patient ID: [REDACTED]
69-year-old male, Software Developer
Blood Type: O

INITIAL VISIT - March 15, 2018
Chief Complaint: Progressive neurological symptoms with morning headaches and right-sided visual/motor deficits

IMAGING:
Initial MRI reveals a 4.2cm right frontal convexity meningioma with significant peritumoral edema. Mass effect on adjacent frontal lobe with 5mm midline shift. T2 hyperintense with heterogeneous enhancement. No calcification noted.

ASSESSMENT:
WHO Grade II meningioma (atypical features on imaging)
High-risk features:
- Size >3cm
- Significant peritumoral edema
- Occupational impact (affecting typing ability)
- History of radiation exposure
- Progressive neurological symptoms

PLAN:
1. Surgical resection recommended urgently
2. Pre-operative optimization with dexamethasone 4mg QID
3. Scheduled for craniotomy within 2 weeks

SURGICAL NOTE - March 29, 2018
Simpson Grade II resection achieved. Minor residual tumor along superior sagittal sinus.
Pathology confirms WHO Grade II meningioma.

FOLLOW-UP - June 15, 2018
Post-operative MRI shows minimal residual disease
Initiated adjuvant radiation therapy: 60 Gy in 30 fractions

FOLLOW-UP - December 20, 2018
Completed radiation therapy
Improved right-sided weakness
Returned to work part-time

2019 VISITS (Every 6 months):
- June: Stable MRI, improving symptoms
- December: No evidence of progression

2020 VISITS:
- June: Small enhancement at surgical site, close monitoring
- December: Enhancement stable, continued surveillance

2021 VISITS:
- June: New 1cm nodule adjacent to resection cavity
- December: Nodule increased to 1.5cm, recommended re-resection

SECOND SURGERY - February 15, 2022
Simpson Grade I resection of recurrence
Pathology: Maintained WHO Grade II status

2022-2024 FOLLOW-UP VISITS (Every 4 months):
- All subsequent MRIs stable
- Patient maintained full-time work
- Annual neuropsychological testing
- Regular ophthalmology monitoring

CURRENT STATUS (2024):
- Disease stable
- Maintained independent work status
- Annual MRI surveillance recommended
- Continue regular neurocognitive assessment

FUNCTIONAL STATUS SCORES:
KPS: 90 - Able to carry on normal activity with minor symptoms
ECOG: 1 - Restricted in physically strenuous activity but ambulatory

MONITORING PROTOCOL:
1. MRI with contrast every 4 months
2. Neuropsychological testing annually
3. Visual field testing every 6 months
4. Regular blood pressure monitoring
5. Occupational therapy assessment as needed

OCCUPATIONAL CONSIDERATIONS:
- Ergonomic workplace modifications implemented
- Regular breaks during computer work
- Reduced screen time when symptomatic
- Modified work schedule as needed

This case demonstrates the importance of aggressive early intervention in WHO Grade II meningiomas, particularly in patients with prior radiation exposure and occupational impact. The patient's positive outcome validates our proactive surgical approach and intensive monitoring protocol.

TREATMENT PLAN:
Given size >3cm, symptoms affecting work performance, and presence of multiple neurological symptoms, recommend immediate surgical intervention. Schedule for craniotomy within 2 weeks.

-------------------

No immediate complications

Started on dexamethasone taper

-------------------

Improved headaches
Return to work part-time

-------------------

Full return to work
Minimal residual symptoms

-------------------

Neurologically stable

-------------------

ANNUAL FOLLOW-UP - 03/18/2016
MRI: Small enhancement at surgical site
Clinically asymptomatic

-------------------

FOLLOW-UP - 04/10/2020
MRI shows 1.2cm recurrence at original site
Recommend SRS to recurrent tumor
Gamma Knife performed 05/15/2020

-------------------

FOLLOW-UP - 10/15/2020
Post-SRS MRI stable
Continues full-time work

[Regular stable follow-ups 2021-2023]

-------------------

LATEST FOLLOW-UP - 01/15/2024
10-year follow-up
MRI shows stable post-treatment changes
No evidence of recurrence
Maintains full professional activities

- No neurological deficits
- Maintains executive function
- Annual MRI surveillance recommended
- Regular cognitive assessments

Given tumor size and symptomatology, surgical intervention would typically be indicated. However, considering patient preference for conservative management:

Patient ID: [REDACTED]
Blood Type: A
Occupation: Librarian/Coffee Roaster

MRI FINDINGS:
- 3.8cm right frontal convexity meningioma
- Significant peritumoral edema
- Mass effect on right frontal lobe
- Enhancement pattern consistent with WHO Grade II meningioma
- Evidence of compression of superior sagittal sinus

ASSESSMENT:
Symptomatic right frontal meningioma with concerning features warranting immediate intervention. High-risk factors include:
- Size >3cm
- Significant peritumoral edema
- Progressive neurological symptoms
- Occupation requiring balance and concentration
WHO Grade: II (preliminary radiological assessment)

TREATMENT PLAN:
Recommend aggressive surgical resection given:
1. Progressive symptoms
2. Size and location
3. Occupational hazards (ladder climbing, chemical exposure)
4. Young age
Schedule for Simpson Grade I resection within 2 weeks.

FOLLOW-UP VISIT - April 30, 2015 (Post-operative)
- Successful gross total resection achieved
- Pathology confirms WHO Grade II meningioma
- Minimal post-operative complications
- Initiated adjuvant radiation therapy (60 Gy/30 fractions)

6-MONTH FOLLOW-UP - October 2015
- Completed radiation therapy
- Improved headaches and vision
- MRI shows no residual tumor
- Cleared to return to work with restrictions on ladder climbing

ANNUAL FOLLOW-UP - March 2016
- Stable imaging
- Returned to full work duties
- Minor fatigue persists
- Continue q6month MRI surveillance

September: No progression, symptoms stable

September: Initiated stereotactic radiosurgery for focal recurrence

Regular neuropsychological assessments

2024 (Current Status):

Chief Complaint: Progressive neurological symptoms including headaches, visual changes, and facial numbness.

IMAGING FINDINGS:
MRI reveals a 3.8cm right sphenoid wing meningioma with significant peritumoral edema, mass effect on the optic nerve, and early signs of compression of adjacent brain tissue. T2 sequence shows hyperintensity, suggesting aggressive growth potential. No calcification noted.

ASSESSMENT:
WHO Grade II meningioma (atypical features on imaging)
Given patient's occupation as a data scientist requiring high cognitive function and visual focus, symptoms significantly impact quality of life and work performance.

TREATMENT PLAN:
Recommend immediate surgical intervention - right pterional craniotomy for gross total resection.
Pre-surgical optimization with dexamethasone 4mg QID for edema management.

-------------------

Findings: Firm, well-vascularized tumor with dural attachment
Pathology: Confirmed WHO Grade II meningioma
Post-op course: Uncomplicated

-------------------

- MRI shows no residual tumor
- Visual symptoms improved
- Returned to work part-time
- Started adjuvant radiotherapy (54 Gy in 30 fractions)

- Complete resolution of headaches
- Full-time work resumed

- No new symptoms

- Recommend increased monitoring frequency

- Continue vigilant monitoring

- Maintained work performance
- No recurrence of symptoms

January 15, 2020

- Recommend stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS)

March 1, 2020

2021-2024 (Quarterly then bi-annual visits)

- Maintained excellent functional status
- Continue surveillance protocol

- Fully functional at work
- No significant neurological deficits

KPS: 90/100 (Able to carry on normal activity with minor symptoms)

MONITORING PROTOCOL:
- MRI every 6 months
- Ophthalmology evaluation annually
- Neuropsychological testing annually
- Continue regular follow-up with neurosurgery

Note: This proactive approach with early intervention and aggressive monitoring has resulted in excellent outcome with maintained quality of life and occupational function.

clinical_notes.aggressive:
CLINICAL NOTES - NEUROSURGERY DEPARTMENT
Patient ID: [REDACTED]
60-year-old male, Blood Type O
Occupation: Research Scientist

INITIAL VISIT - March 15, 2014
Presenting Symptoms: Progressive headaches (3 months), right eye blurred vision, gait instability, personality changes, recent focal seizure (left hand), word-finding difficulties.
Imaging: MRI reveals 4.2cm right frontal convexity meningioma with significant peritumoral edema, mass effect on adjacent frontal lobe. T2 hyperintense with heterogeneous enhancement.
WHO Grade: Suspected Grade II (based on imaging characteristics)
Plan: Recommend immediate surgical intervention due to size, symptoms, and critical location.

SURGICAL INTERVENTION - April 2, 2014
Procedure: Right frontal craniotomy for tumor resection
Simpson Grade II resection achieved
Pathology: WHO Grade II atypical meningioma
Post-op course: Uncomplicated

FOLLOW-UP VISIT - July 15, 2014
Status: Improved symptoms, minimal residual word-finding difficulties
Treatment: Completed adjuvant radiation therapy (60 Gy/30 fractions)
Imaging: Post-radiation MRI shows no residual tumor
Plan: q6month MRI surveillance

2015 VISITS (January & July)
Status: Stable, returned to research work with accommodations
Imaging: No recurrence
Neurological exam: Normal

2016 VISITS (January & July)
Status: Maintaining function, occasional mild headaches
Imaging: Small enhancement at surgical site (July) - close monitoring advised
Plan: Continue q6month surveillance

2017 VISITS (January & July)
Status: Stable
Imaging: Enhancement stable, no progression
Neurological exam: Intact

2018 VISITS (January & July)
Status: Reports increased work-related stress
Imaging: Slight increase in enhancement
Plan: More frequent MRI monitoring (q4months)

2019 VISITS (Q4monthly)
March: Small focus of recurrence noted
June: Decision for repeat surgery
August: Second craniotomy performed
Pathology: Confirmed Grade II recurrence
December: Post-op recovery satisfactory

2020-2021 VISITS (Q6monthly)
Status: Stable post second surgery
Imaging: No evidence of recurrence
Plan: Continued surveillance

2022-2023 VISITS (Q6monthly)
Status: Maintained good functional status
Imaging: Stable post-treatment changes
Occupational status: Modified research duties

CURRENT STATUS (2024)
Patient maintains good functional status with minimal deficits
Regular MRI surveillance continues
Working part-time in research capacity

PERFORMANCE SCORES:
KPS: 90 (Able to carry on normal activity with minor symptoms)
ECOG: 1 (Restricted in physically strenuous activity but ambulatory)

MONITORING PROTOCOL:
- MRI with contrast q6months
- Neurological examination q6months
- Cognitive assessment annually
- Quality of life assessments q6months
- Occupational exposure monitoring
- Seizure prophylaxis maintained

LONG-TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
1. Continue surveillance imaging
2. Maintain modified work schedule
3. Regular cognitive assessments
4. Monitor for radiation-induced changes
5. Lifestyle modifications to reduce stress

Note: This case demonstrates the importance of aggressive initial intervention and close monitoring in WHO Grade II meningiomas, particularly given the patient's cognitive-demanding occupation.
